column4: and it was not long until he came to the sedgy banks where his little boat was waiting for him. As he stepped into the curragh the moon was rising above the mountains. He rowed on until he came to the hut
column5: and having moored the boat to the door
column6: he put on the water-dress and the crystal helmet
column7: and taking the spear in his hand
column8: he leaped over the side of the curragh
column9: and sank down and down until he touched the bottom. Then he walked along without minding where he was going
column10: and the only light he had was the shimmering moonlight
column11: which descended as faintly through the waters as if it came through muffled glass. He had not gone very far when he heard a horrible hissing
column12: and straight before him he saw what he thought were two flaming coals. After a few more steps he found himself face to face with the dragon of the lake
column13: the guardian of the palace of the fairy queen.
